text: Again, how in French do you say later, literally more late?
Plus tard.
Or bigger, literally more big?
Plus grand.
So, as we mentioned earlier, in French you will only ever use more in order to describe something as bigger.
It's always more big.
You don't add er on to the end of it, you just simply add more, more comfortable, more intelligent, more big, more late.
The word for slow in French is lent.
And the word for slowly is lentement.
The ment at the end is the equivalent of the li in English as in slowly or quickly.
So again, slow is lent, but slowly is lentement.
How would you say more slowly in French?
Plus lentement.
To speak in French is parler.
Parler.
You may be familiar with this from the English term parley, to parley, to speak with someone, to negotiate in a way.
So, how would you say to speak more slowly?
Parler plus lentement.
Let's change that to a command and give it a bit of force and say, speak more slowly.
Parler plus lentement.
Let's be a bit more polite now and say, can you speak more slowly?
Pouvez-vous parler plus lentement?
What was continue in French, continue?
How would you say, can you continue?
Pouvez-vous continuer?
Now give continue as an order and say, continue.
Continue.
How would you say, continue straight ahead?
Continue tout droit.
Continue tout droit.
And to turn in French, how would you say to turn?
Tourner.
So, how would you say, turn to the right?
Tourner à droite.
Again, you may remember that in English we have adroit, which means skillful or rightly, to the right.
So, again, turn to the right.
Tourner à droite.
Or, of course, you may say, turn to the left, which would be...
Tourner à gauche.
And, of course, we have the term gauche in English, which suggests people are unsophisticated, cack-handed,
and originally it implies they're left-handed, even though we might find such ideas unacceptable today.
So, how would you say in French, after the cathedral, turn left?
Tourner à gauche.
Tourner à gauche.
And, of course, we have the term gauche.
So, how would you say, turn to the right?
To the right?
Tourner à gauche.
So, how would you say, turn to the right?
Tourner à gauche, on the right?
Tourner à gauche.
And, of course, we have the term gauche.
And, of course, we have the term gauche.
So, how would you say, turn to the right?
On the right?
On the right?
To the right?
On the right?
